Built to help admissions teams understand my work

This website showcases a selection of my software projects hosted on GitHub. It is designed specifically for university application reviewers to quickly understand my interests, technical strengths, and project impact.

Learn More Browse Projects Get in touch

What you'll find here

  • Selected projects with clear descriptions and what they do
  • Technologies used, design decisions, and import features
  • Links to source code and documentation on GitHub
  • Hobby projects, software and hardware projects, and academic projects

Why it exists

GitHub repositories can be dense and technical. This site presents highlights and context so that admissions readers can quickly assess the scope, rigor, and outcomes of my work.

Selected Work

A quick visual tour of a few representative projects. Click any image to view it larger.

Titanic Survival Using Machine Learning

Based on user-given passenger class, passenger age and passenger gender, and using real Titanic passenger data and Machine Learning, this program will tell you if you are likely to survive.

Tech: Python, Machine Learning, scikit-learn, pandas, numpy

Handwritten Digit Recognition

A Tkinter handwritten digit recognition app with a custom ML engine. Draw digits for real-time prediction with confidence, give thumbs up/down feedback to improve accuracy, undo, debug tools, array visualization, pattern management, duplicate removal, pattern count display, error-handled pattern storage, autocentering and storage optimization.

Focus: GUI, user experience, performance/accuracy

Arduino and Python Morse Translator

A Python project that converts user-input phrases into Morse code and flashes them using an Arduino board. Supports repeated playback and handles letters, numbers, and symbols. Uses pyfirmata2 for Arduino communication.

Highlights: Hardware and Software
